description.narrative: In Afghanistan, the ERF is an emergency fund at the exclusive disposal of NGOs, operating under the overall management and oversight of the Humanitarian Coordinator. It provides recipient organisations with a rapid and flexible in-country funding mechanism. Projects responding to unforeseen or new developments are prioritized for funding. The ERF may also provide funding to life-saving activities with critical gaps in the Common Humanitarian Action Plan and bridge funding to meet short-term emergency needs. The CHAP 2014 identifies emergency health, acute food insecurity and IDP assistance as headline priorities. The provincial needs and vulnerability ranking table in the CHAP places Hilmand, Kunar, Badghis, Nangarhar and Ghor at the top, as provinces with high needs across sectors. The ERF grants have a maximum value of USD 500.000,- and a maximum duration of 6 months. Whereas the ERF has focused predominantly on shelter interventions in response to natural hazards in Northern Afghanistan, the 2013 ERF encourages NGO partners to respond to conflict-induced needs in Southern and Eastern regions. An effort will be made to channel ERF grants to eligible National NGOs with access to extremely vulnerable populations affected by conflict. That being said, proposals for emergency projects in response to natural disasters will also be considered on their own merit.
